image.altText: Flight crew load a stretcher into a helicopter on a hospital flight pad.

items.synopsis: Rangers say a woman has suffered bites to the lower half of her body after dingoes followed her into the water while she was running along a beach at K'gari (Fraser Island).

title.children: Jogger flown to hospital after being attacked by four dingoes on K'gari

image.altText: Images of six people in a digital collage on shapes that appear to form buildings. There are two cranes on top of these shapes.

items.synopsis: For years, Dyldam's string of company collapses has anguished apartment buyers, angered subcontractors, and frustrated liquidators.

title.children: The family empire behind a succession of company collapses, defective buildings and unpaid tradies

image.altText: Flu vaccination

items.synopsis: Most of the children in hospital were diagnosed with influenza B and only one had been vaccinated.

title.children: Queenslanders to get free flu jabs after child dies with influenza B

image.altText: Silhouette of an Australian solder in Afghanistan.

items.synopsis: Two years after the Royal Commission into Defence and Veteran Suicide was formed, one of the commissioners tells the opening hearing in Adelaide that key themes to have emerged so far include a "terrible ADF culture" and "bullying, harassment, and abuses of power".

title.children: 'Terrible culture' and 'bullying' within ADF among key themes confronted by royal commission

image.altText: the PWC sign inside its lobby, with a woman in a red jacket walking by

items.synopsis: Until now, the big four accounting firms had built themselves an aura of credibility and trust in government and corporate Australia, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: How four companies infiltrated governments and took home $10 billion

image.altText: A woman crouches next to a campfire on a beach at sunset

items.synopsis: Australians have a reputation for being a sociable bunch, but we're spending more time alone than ever before. Experts say social media, living alone and a fashion for being busy is driving the trend.

title.children: 'A nation without friends': Why aren't Australians socialising like they used to?

image.altText: Spain's Carlos Alcaraz celebrates with the trophy after winning his final match against Serbia's Novak Djokovic.

items.synopsis: Carlos Alcaraz defeats Novak Djokovic to win Wimbledon in a five-set epic that saw a 26-minute service game, superb tennis and Djokovic destroying a racquet on the net post.

title.children: No-one gave Carlos Alcaraz much of a chance, but the Spaniard won Wimbledon and left Novak Djokovic fuming

image.altText: A black and white cut-out photo of Wendie Renard kicking a soccerball, against a pale orange background

items.synopsis: More than 700 of the world's best football players will take to stadium pitches all over Australia when FIFA 2023 kicks off this week. The ABC has crunched the data — these are the stars and breakthrough talents you should be looking out for.

title.children: At 189cm, Wendie Renard is one of the biggest aerial threats both in attack and defence

image.altText: Rescuers wade waist-deep in floodwaters in front of a submerged bus.

items.synopsis: Days of torrential rain leaves dozens dead and at least nine missing, many of whom were trapped in a flooded tunnel in the central city of Cheongju.

title.children: South Korean president orders all-out effort as flood death toll rises to 39

image.altText: A young couple smiling, the mother's holding a baby. They are in a green paddock surrounded by dairy cows.

items.synopsis: Tasmanian Sharefarmers of the Year Nathan and Cassidy Lawrence are living the dream in north-west Tasmania, after being given a chance that "doesn't come up very often".

title.children: How these young farmers broke into one of Australia's priciest property markets

image.altText: Margot Robbie dressed as Barbie wearing a black and white striped swimsuit, white sunglasses, miniature children holding dolls

items.synopsis: Barbie's longevity may come down to the fact that she has not remained the same, adapting to appeal to changing societal values.

title.children: Barbie began life as a blonde. Her evolution could be the key to her success

image.altText: Image of pink patties on a conveyer belt.

items.synopsis: Alternative protein producers in Australia are navigating a period of reset following a dramatic year of stock market price falls for major meat substitute companies.

title.children: Plant-based food industry makes leap forward as scientists discover missing 'fatty' meat flavour

image.altText: Image of police loading up a search boat moored to a jetty.

items.synopsis: Police in WA's Pilbara will deploy drones and divers to search for a man in his 20s missing after a boat sank off Dampier on Saturday night.

title.children: Pilbara marine search enters second day after weekend boat crash

image.altText: A grainy photograph of a young woman holding up a yellow soccer shirt with AUSTRALIA on the back

items.synopsis: Sandra Brentnall was just 17 when she scored Australia's first international goal in women's soccer, despite wearing boots that were two sizes too big.

title.children: Sandra scored Australia's first international goal in women's soccer wearing boots stuffed with newspaper

image.altText: Australian football players

items.synopsis: From prize money to collective bargaining to a full-time A-League Women, the Matildas have used their platform to advocate for the entire women's game.

title.children: Matildas sound equality call on eve of 2023 Women's World Cup

image.altText: A man hosing his garden.

items.synopsis: With the cost-of-living crisis, it's becoming harder for Yousuf Mohammed and his father to keep themselves afloat, as well as dozens of extended family members overseas.

title.children: Yousuf struggles to pay the bills, but he worries about the 25 relatives he provides for in a Rohingya refugee camp

image.altText: Some drugs in pill and powder form.

items.synopsis: From pink cocaine and dangerous opioids to a never-before-seen drug dubbed CanKet, Australia's first drug-checking service has made history-making discoveries in 12 months.

title.children: From pink cocaine to dangerous opioids — what Australia's first drug-checking site found in its inaugural year

image.altText: A female gymnast puts chalk on her feet.

items.synopsis: Gymnastics Australia declares itself financially incapable of assisting abuse survivors three years after publicly pledging its commitment to a redress scheme.

title.children: Gymnastics Australia backs away from pledge to assist survivors of childhood sexual abuse

image.altText: A white police truck is parked on the side of the road next to a taped-off field

items.synopsis: Jerry Robertson has appeared in Alice Springs Local Court after being charged with murder, breaching a domestic violence order and being armed with an offensive weapon at night.

title.children: Man charged with murdering his partner at Alice Springs bush camp

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: The ASX is following Wall Street's subdued lead from Friday with flat trade, while consulting firm Deloitte's leadership are being grilled in parliament. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX flat at start, Deloitte faces Senate grilling

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian dollar has declined during morning trade, with the share market moving in the opposite direction. The Aussie dollar was worth 68.2 US cents by 12:25pm AEST, down around a quarter of a per cent since early this morning. The ASX has moved the other way, having traded slightly lower early in the session, but being flat around the middle of the trading day. The ASX 200 was up just 1 point at 7,304 points around 12:30pm AEST, while the All Ords was dead flat at 7,517. At 12:30pm the top movers up were: Medibank Private: +3.9% to $3.48 Domain Holdings: +2.9% to $3.85 Whitehaven Coal: +2.1% to $6.79 IPH Ltd: +2.1% to $8.105 Viva Energy: +1.7% to $3.07 Down: Endeavour Group: -10.2% to $5.62 IGO Ltd: -5.2% to $15.28 Paladin Energy: -3.2% to $0.76 Nickel Industries: -3% to $0.8825 Lifestyle Communities: -2.8% to $16.48
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian dollar eases, shares rise

The
Aussie dollar was worth 68.2 US cents
by 12:25pm AEST, down around a quarter of a per cent since early this morning.
The ASX has moved the other way, having traded slightly lower early in the session, but being flat around the middle of the trading day.
The
ASX 200 was up just 1 point at 7,304 points
around 12:30pm AEST, while the
All Ords was dead flat at 7,517
At 12:30pm the top movers up were:
Medibank Private: +3.9% to $3.48

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Greens senator Barbara Pocock has gone hard on Deloitte, seeking details of the contract where Deloitte has admitted breaching protocols around the handling of confidential government information. However, Deloitte's executives said they cannot even reveal which government department the work was related to without checking with that department first. That response prompted an outraged response from the senator. "You are opaque in the information you provide, even when clear notice is provided," Ms Pocock said, noting that this lack of transparency was undermining any public confidence in the consulting sector. The senator asked Deloitte on notice which contract was involved, with which department, what specific information was misused and with what consequences.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Pocock seeks details of government information misused by Deloitte

children.content: Greens senator Barbara Pocock
has gone hard on Deloitte, seeking details of the contract where Deloitte has admitted breaching protocols around the handling of confidential government information.
However, Deloitte's executives said they cannot even reveal which government department the work was related to without checking with that department first.
That response prompted an outraged response from the senator.

"You are opaque in the information you provide, even when clear notice is provided," Ms Pocock said, noting that this lack of transparency was undermining any public confidence in the consulting sector.
The senator asked Deloitte on notice which contract was involved, with which department, what specific information was misused and with what consequences.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: One of PwC's responses, albeit belatedly after the scandal around leaks of confidential government tax information had escalated, has been to split of its government consulting business into a separate firm, which it is planning to sell for a dollar to a private equity firm. However, Deloitte's executives have told today's Senate hearing that they have no plan to do something similar. "We have no intention of ring-fencing our business," the company's submission to the inquiry noted. Deloitte's chief executive Adam Powlick said the firm's interests were aligned with those of its clients, including the federal government. "We're a client serving organisation," he said. "You're a profit-making business," interjected Senator Deborah O'Neill. Ms O'Neill pointed out that government work now accounts for around a quarter of Deloitte's revenues.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Deloitte has 'no intention' of splitting out government consulting

children.content: One of PwC's responses, albeit belatedly after the scandal around leaks of confidential government tax information had escalated, has been to split of its government consulting business into a separate firm, which it is planning to sell for a dollar to a private equity firm.
However, Deloitte's executives have told today's Senate hearing that they have no plan to do something similar.
"We have no intention of ring-fencing our business," the company's submission to the inquiry noted.
Deloitte's chief executive Adam Powlick said the firm's interests were aligned with those of its clients, including the federal government.
"We're a client serving organisation," he said.
"You're a profit-making business," interjected Senator Deborah O'Neill.
Ms O'Neill pointed out that government work now accounts for around a quarter of Deloitte's revenues.

image.altText: A woman with dark hair and earrings looks at the camera with a neutral expression

items.synopsis: Six months on from when Angie Fuller disappeared from the side of an outback highway, and a homicide investigation was launched, police are considering offering a reward for information.

title.children: Angie Fuller disappeared from Alice Springs six months ago. What do we know?

image.altText: Black and white photo of Jane Birkin in the 1960s

items.synopsis: French media report the 1960s wild child was found dead at her home in Paris.

title.children: Jane Birkin, who sang, acted and inspired a fashion coup dies

image.altText: A sick horse being treated in a stable

items.synopsis: Agriculture Victoria says 10 horses have died from mysterious causes in recent days on the Mornington Peninsula and in south-east Melbourne and south-west Victoria.

title.children: Horse owners urged to be vigilant after 10 animals suddenly die

image.altText: Image of fire on the deck of Antarctic supply ship Everest.

items.synopsis: The crew of an Australian-leased resupply vessel were "unsure if they (would) have to abandon ship" when large flames began erupting from its engine room in the Southern Ocean two years ago, Freedom of Information documents reveal.

title.children: 'Unsure if they will have to abandon ship': New details reveal danger of Antarctic ship fire

image.altText: A person with short hair leans against a sandstone wall and smiles.

items.synopsis: Tasmania is the first state to officially recognise those who identify as asexual, adding the A to the LGBTIQ+ initialism on all government documents.

title.children: First Australian state officially adds 'A' to recognised LGBTIQ+ term

image.altText: Soldiers in uniform attend to children in a jungle in Colombia

items.synopsis: Four Colombian Indigenous children who survived an aeroplane crash and lived for more than five weeks in the jungle have been released from hospital after a 34-day stay.

title.children: Colombian children who survived five weeks in jungle released from hospital

image.altText: Airport security screens passengers.

items.synopsis: Some countries no longer require you to remove your shoes when passing through security — but taking out your laptop is still mostly required, writes Doug Drury.

title.children: Why you have to take out your laptop — and other fascinating facts about airport security

image.altText: Two young boys in sport uniforms, one giving a thumbs up, with a male coach in the background

items.synopsis: An inclusive rugby league team is learning skills and meeting new people ahead of playing in a NRL curtain raiser when the Dolphins play the Bulldogs in Bundaberg.

title.children: All abilities footy helps country kid overcome struggle to find place in traditional sporting clubs

image.altText: An illustration of the influenza virus with the letters A, B, H1N1 and H5N1 floating about.

items.synopsis: Influenza B remains at concerning levels just as NSW students begin to return to schools from holidays and two children die after contracting the virus — a year 9 student from the Central Coast and an 11-year-old in Queensland.

title.children: School's in and so is the flu, so what should parents be looking out for as cases surge?

image.altText: David Warner looks behind him

items.synopsis: The case for and against David Warner retaining his opener spot as Australia faces tough selection choices ahead of the fourth Ashes Test at Old Trafford.

title.children: David Warner poses a problem at the top of the batting order, but what other options are there?

image.altText: A group of walkers stand in a grassy campsite with their arms around each other, smiling.

items.synopsis: News Breakfast co-host Lisa Millar swapped the studio for a 250-kilometre walk over Victoria's coastline, forest and riverbanks — from Portland to Nelson on the South Australian border — for an episode of ABC TV's Back Roads.

title.children: Lifting the veil on one of Australia's most beautiful, but least known, long walks

image.altText: light beams filter through sea water as seaweed reaches upwards, fish swim through

items.synopsis: Groundbreaking new research shows the climate benefits of protecting and restoring underwater kelp forests could be equivalent to planting a billion trees.

title.children: The underwater 'Amazon' off Australia's coast that could help tackle climate change
